God's mercy either does-or does not make up for insufficient penance; if it does, discernnrent in the priest is unnecessary3 if it does not, we must find injustice everywhere, different priests enjoining different penances for the very same sin. lt is useless here to fall back upon the notion of expiation in Purgatory‚ for an insufficient penante may result in sending the penitent to Hell; and even if not, the sufferings of Purgatory are the most severe of penalties. The very difficolt science of enjoining proper penances is at present abandoned, and arbitrary penances are given; because, if the ancient canons were followed, no one would confess. Yet what was once possible is possible even now, The real motive of this conduct is worldly gain; these priests prefer to impose fines on their penitents, and, like bad doctors, ought to be hung. The law requiring the penitent to be alone, heretically implies that God can possibly not be present, that no confession is valid‚ if overheard, and it gives occasion to sins of lust. Solus besides can not apply to a woman.

Passing rapidly by the question of the seal of confession, to which he objects more at length in another part of the work, Wyclif points out the rigour of the law obliging every one to confess to the priest hierarchically appointed. Why should we have to ask leave to go to another, when we have good reasons for acting thus? And if the tproper priest> alone can, according to the decree, grant the required permission, it follows that his Bishop has no right to do so, and therefore no jurisdictiou. God gives the right to hear confessions at the same time aa He gives¹ the priest- hood. .

No formula of absolution is to be found in Scripture; all Christiaus can grant absolution. The priest, not knowing whether his peniteat is contrite, is ignorant whether the absolution really takes place, or no: yet he utters the sacramental words - perhaps a falsehood. lf the absolution is given provisionally, then the pardonis uncertain, and any other man could give it just as well. Augustine himself says that the absolution of a priest separated from the communion of the Church is not valid3 this may possibly be true of the whole present hierarchy.
